awards.title: The International Association for the Exchange of Students for Technical Experience (IAESTE) trainee program
awards.description: IAESTE Grant for a traineeship in the Netherlands, at Architecture office Evelein in Amsterdam.The International Association for the Exchange of Students for Technical Experience (IAESTE) is an independent, non-profit and non-political student exchange organisation. It provides students in technical degrees with paid, course-related training abroad and employers with highly skilled, highly motivated international trainees. With more than 80 member countries and over 4000 traineeships exchanged each year, it is the largest organisation of its kind in the world.

awards.title: Who is Who among American High School Students 1987-1988, USA
awards.description:
Who's Who Among American High School Students is a web site and publication (owned and managed by Educational Communications Inc.) that listed what it deemed to be high school students "who have excelled in academics, extracurricular activities and community service". Only 5% of the best High School students in the USA are included in the year book. This book provides a short biography.

Who's Who Among American High School Students compiled and published an annual edition in which students' names and achievements are listed. According to the website, people who accept nomination for inclusion in the book are sometimes qualified for various scholarship opportunities.
awards.issuer: Lake Forest, IL : Educational Communications, Inc., 1998.

projects.title: Healthcare Design Conference 2012
projects.description:
TAMU First Look Colloquium—The International Perspective
This program is presented by Texas A&M University
Saturday, November 3, 2012

The Netherlands Perspective—Predicting the Future Performance of Health Facility Designs

Sanja Durmisevic, PhD and Eliane Schreuder, Msc

This First Look interactive workshop will discuss how advances in the application of Evidence Based Design methodology help design practitioners. There is a lack of information regarding how the built environment influences aspects such as patient well-being, patient safety, and staff satisfaction. Presenters will propose a technique for analyzing the influence of the complex, multi-factorial healthcare environment on patient and staff outcomes in order to identify areas for improvement. They will discuss the advantages of using fuzzy logic and discuss methods that support research on the performance of a complex healthcare setting using a case study example of a Dutch Hospital.

projects.title: Innovation in Design and Management of Healthcare Facilities and Healthy Environments
projects.description:
3TU Research Day
Coordinator: Sanja Durmisevic

As a part of the International Conference ‘Perspectives on European Healthcare Design and Planning: Achieving Excellence in Diversity’ organised by TNO/Dutch Center for Health Assets in 2009, three Universities of Technology (TU Delft, TU Eindhoven and University of Twente) organised a Research Day for researchers and practitioners on ‘Innovation in Design and Management of Healthcare Facilities and Healthy Environments’. During this day there were a number of activities including (inter)national speakers who presented their views on recent developments, the presentation of scientific papers as well as a ‘Research Corner’ where participants can gather knowledge on the most recent developments in the field. This Research Day aimed to bring together researchers and practitioners by providing a number of opportunities to exchange ideas regarding a variety of issues related to design and management of healthcare facilities and healthy environments.

projects.title: Sarajevo Green Design Festival 2011
projects.description:
Invited lecture 'Users'needs and built environment'
Sarajevo, Bosnia-Herzegovina

Often, a designer ‘assumes’ what the user requirements are and according to these assumptions the architect designs a building. Yet the end result – a building, or an urban plan - should not be a sum of the personal assumptions but rather a product of design decisions based on the best available evidence, and in this case those are the needs of the users in a specific context, weather that is a mobility hub, a hospital or a city district. But to be able to obtain the ‘best available evidence’ there should also be ways to study the successful designs and to learn from them. We should be able to understand why certain environments are more successful than the others? What the secret of that success is? What are the design intentions and how successful where they? In this lecture, Sanja Durmisevic proposed the way of dealing with this topic and explain the added value of the proposed approach.

projects.title: Thinking differently, designing differently | 1st Research Day | Architecture in Health: Between science and practice
projects.description:
Coordinators: Joram Nauta (College Bouw Zorginstellingen) and Sanja Durmisevic (TU Delft)

The Platform Architecture in Health organized in 2008 its first Research Day under a title "Thinking differently, designing differently: Architecture in Health, between science and practice"

On this day, the researchers in healthcare, architecture and the built environment presented their scientific research or design. Next to networking, the goal was to explore and identifying research at the intersection between architecture and health. The organizers of this day aimed to identify chances and new opportunities for strengthening research for 'architecture in healthcare' and to develop new knowledge in this area.

authors.headline: Research & Customer Success Manager at &beyond sales engineers

profile_positions.description:
Healthy Urban Environments are not a finished product; it is a process, a way towards healing our social, economic and physical environments in a context of cultural and local diversity. Using the best available knowledge and a variety of methods, with a user-centered focus, I am contributing to  a realization of Healthy Urban Environments, both on a scale of a building and urban domain/neighborhoods. 

In the coming years, the challenge will be to rebuild our environments and heal the domains that need the healing. Apart from what is technically possible, our perceptions, emotions and behaviors play an important role in a process of healing. When developing new areas by using best available evidence and monitoring impacts it is possible to see directly the effects of our action. By healing our environments locally, our environment will become both wealthier and healthier globally.

The societal challenges of today and tomorrow, environmental crisis and the economic development are tied together and are a result of our actions taken in the past. With a shared vision across disciplines and across borders, I believe that it is possible to pave a path to healing our environments and shape the desired reality by bringing closer together science and practice and engagement of citizens and users in shaping our common future. Only together we can contribute to successfully rebuilding our future the way we want it to be.

volunteer_experiences.role: Parent representative and PTA (Parent Teacher Association)
volunteer_experiences.description: Education of our children, the culture, practised values at school and the shared responsibility of parents, teachers and governance are the basis of a sustainable and healthy society of the future. It is my privilege to be the voice of the parents and represent them at PTA and take necessary steps to help solve individual challenges or propose systematical changes where necessary in order to improve the wellbeing of the children and staff and through open communication contribute to a shared vision among all parties involved in shaping generations to come.

volunteer_experiences.role: Board member and Secretary department Delft, Rijswijk and Pijnacker-Nootdorp
volunteer_experiences.description: A success of a society is not only measured by the wealth but by the way the society takes care of those who, for a range of different reasons, temporarily cannot manage on their own. With my work at Humanitas I am contributing to inclusive society, a society where no one is left behind. Humanitas is a nonprofit association and one of the main social services and community building organizations of the Netherlands. We advocate humanist values such as: equality (of volunteer and client), responsibility (for yourself and others in society) and autonomy (the activities are geared towards ensuring that the clients can once more take control of their lives).
